Title: Anzac Day 2014
Description: Follow the ABC's live blog as Australia commemorates the 99th anniversary of the Anzac landings at Gallipoli, and honours all the men and women who have served the country.

Posts.Content:
This concludes our live blog of Anzac Day 2014.

Thousands of Australians have made the journey to Gallipoli to experience the dawn service where the Anzac legend was born.

They also gathered in France, Belgium, Papua New Guinea and Afghanistan to honour the men and women who have fought and died in war.

Thousands more attended ceremonies and marches across Australia, with 80,000 people visiting the Shire of Remembrance in Melbourne for its dawn service.

In Canberra, Prince William and Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, laid a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

Thanks for sharing your experiences of this solemn day with us.

While the blog may be closing, you can read our story as well as visit our special Anzac Day website.
Serving members of Australia's Defence Forces send home messages to their loved ones.

ABC correspondent Philip Williams says the number of people attending the dawn service at Anzac Cove were down this year to less than 5,000.

"There are all sorts of theories. One of them was that perhaps people are holding off, hoping to win the ballot for one of those 12,000 seats for the 100th anniversary. Then it was perhaps too late for them to make travel arrangements. 

"There is a natural fluctuation, too. Perhaps not so many people are drawn to Gallipoli. It may have been Australians based in Europe drifting more to Villers-Bretonneux. 

"That has become a major site in itself as well on this day, so it's not as though there is competition, they are quite different in complex and different theatres of war that they are commemorating, but really the organisers didn't seem upset by that. 

"They said this is a chance for us to make sure everything is right for next year."

The State Library of New South Wales holds more than 1,000 collections of World War I diaries and letters as well as maps, photos and objects from the battlefield. Its curator Elise Edmonds has told ABC News 24 that reading the diaries helps shed some light on the experiences of men and women on the frontline.

Here's another of the fantastic Anzac Day photos you've been sharing with us on social media.

This one has been taken by Patricia Woods at the parade in the Brisbane suburb of Bulimba.

Women in uniform: remembering those who paved the way

Jean Nysen was just a teenager when World War II broke out.

The 92-year-old reflects on life in the Australian Navy, then and now.
#ANZACDay2014 in Bellingen NSW #abcanzac http://pbs.twimg.com/media/BmDBQqACEAA5wS_.jpg

One son's quest to track down his father's POW mate

Anzac Day is a time for remembering. But what does the family of a veteran remember if the soldier doesn't talk?

When John Larkin was growing up, he had no idea of what horrors his father, Frank (pictured), had been through in World War II.

But a former comrade of his father's, who was by Frank Larkin's side during those dark days, has changed all that.

"At home, every city, every country town has its memorials. It's symbolic graves for those who did not return. 

"Here among their actual graves, we can sense again the beating of the long, stilled hearts of those who gave their all for our young country. 

"Their loss has left us the poorer. With these great-hearted men amongst us, who knows what we might be today."

- General David Hurley, Chief of the Australian Defence Force
FT: Once in front, they never looked back. Collingwood surges to 12.11 (83) to 8.12 (60) Anzac Day win over Essendon. #AFLPiesBombers

Unlike the dawn service at Anzac Cove, the ceremony at Lone Pine is an Australian commemoration. A service will also be held at Chunuk Bair for New Zealanders, a significant battle site for our neighbours across the Tasman.

"Lone Pine has a special place in Australia's national story as a site of one of the bloodiest and hardest fought actions of the Gallipoli campaign. 

"For four days in early August 1915 on this site, Australians and Turks struggled in brutal hand-to-hand combat until the area was choked with the wounded, dying and the dead. 

"An unknown Australian officer wrote the following words to the parents of one of the Australian dead: 'The sites in Lone Pine were too terrible for words, but the way those chaps took the trenches and the way they held on was the equal of any feat of arms ever accomplished'."

- James Larsen, Australian ambassador to Turkey
A round of applause is given to veterans of all nations of any conflict present at the Lone Pine ceremony.
Lone Pine Memorial

ABC News 24
@ABCNews24

Blow darts and broken bones: four WWII veterans remember

Many WWII veterans are now well into their 90s and there is a danger their stories could go unrecorded.

ABC producer Lincoln Tyner recently spoke to four South Australian veterans who each performed remarkable deeds.
Lone Pine commemoration about to get underway at Gallipoli, @PhilWilliamsABC is there and joins us now: ab.co/abcnews24 #abcanzac
Watch aerial vision taken over key historical sites at Gallipoli. (Music: O Valiant Hearts, performed by The Royal Military College Band)

The ABC's Serpil Senelmis has shared her reflections of the dawn service at Anzac Cove:

"As a new dawn broke over Gallipoli, thousands of Australians descended to Anzac Cove to commemorate the 99th anniversary of Anzac Day.

"Young and old proudly donned the green and gold, braving the chill of the air in blankets and sleeping bags.

"Prior to the official dawn service, those who made the pilgrimage enjoyed a reflective program which included a moving performance from the Gallipoli Symphony (inspired by Omar Faruk Tekbilek), a powerful speech read by New Zealand student Cyril Bassett, and a spine-chilling performance from Australian Indigenous performer William Barton.

"The dawn service once again reminded us of those powerful words from Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, Turkey's first president, when he consoled mothers by stating their sons were lying in a friendly country. 

"This warm embrace, which turned Australian and New Zealanders from foe to friend, was ever present again today.

"At the first glint of sun, the mood turned sombre and thousands stood still to reflect on the memory and meaning of the commemoration."
Young proud Aussies leaving ANZAC Cove as the 99th anniversary wraps up #anzac http://pbs.twimg.com/media/BmChkVRIYAAAUoC.jpg
Incredibly Collingwood have levelled the scores at half-time at MCG. Magpies and Bombers both 6.5.41 #AFLPiesDons ab.co/1mKCYKS

A 46-year-old man will face court tomorrow for wielding a knife at Brisbane's Anzac Day march, reports the ABC's Alyse Edwards.     

Police say the man was causing a disturbance in the CBD around 10.30am, and when they tried to approach him produced the weapon.

He has been charged with a string of offences including serious assault of police, going armed to cause fear and possession of a dangerous drug.

ANZAC Day commemorations in Beaudesert, Queensland; the service was very well put together with significant care given to Veterans and the community's young people playing a central role in proceedings! #anzacday #abcanzac #commemorations #remembrance #lestweforget #armedforces #veterans #scenicrim #beaudesert #queensland

Essendon tearaway leaders after the first quarter at the MCG leading Collingwood 5.4.34 to 1.1.3 ab.co/1mKCYKS #AFLPiesBombers

The ABC's Louisa Rebgetz reports that World War II veterans have taken part in a special mass in Brisbane using the same communion set used with Anzac troops in Gallipoli in 1915.

The former minister of St Andrew's Uniting Church in Brisbane was also the army chaplain at Gallipoli and brought the set back to the church in 1919. 

WWII veteran Lionel Rackley, 92, says he felt the presence of his lost comrades during today's service.  

"I always feel Anzac Day. I didn't really need that to feel that, but I did feel it and I think it is wonderful we can hark back to history that far in this particular church," he said.
In case you missed it earlier today, here is Prime Minister Tony Abbott's address at the national Anzac Day ceremony in Canberra
#ANZAC day dawn service - forever remembered! @ Hyde Park Corner instagram.com/p/nMz8f6RM_l/

Pride and colour on display at Turkey's unique Gallipoli commemorations

For the Turks, remembering Anzac Day is an entirely different affair to the sombre tone at dawn services across Australia, writes ABC Middle East correspondent Hayden Cooper.

Thousands are flocking to pubs across Australia to take part in the nation's Anzac Day pastime - two-up.

 
Tom Forbes
@tomforbes72
Come in spinner. Two up at the Surfers RSL. @abcnews_qld @abcgoldcoast pic.twitter.com/LUNCMotB7N

Back in Australia, the traditional AFL blockbuster between Collingwood and Essendon is about to get underway in front of 90,000 people at the MCG.
The national anthems of France and Australia and a final blessing bring the official part of the service in Villers-Bretonneux to an end.
The Last Post at Villers-Bretonneux
Official wreaths are now laid by Julie Bishop and Jean-Francois Cordet and other dignitaries.
Australian National Memorial, Villers-Bretonneux

Jean-Francois Cordet, prefet of Picardy and of the Somme, delivers a message from Kader Arif, the French secretary of state:

My thoughts are with all those soldiers who came from Australia 100 years ago to fight on our soil for a shared ideal we call freedom.

In forging their destiny to that of France, Australians have made World War I the foundation of a shared history between our nations.

I am filled with admiration for the way in which Australians live and keep alive their memory.

"The individual experience of each soldier contributes to the greatest story of the whole of what happened here on the Western Front and on the battle fields of Turkey, and of the enormous sacrifices that were made in our nation's name. 

"The loss of more than 60,000 Australian lives in World War I, from a total population of less than 5 million at that time, meant that few, if any Australians, were left untouched by the scourge of war."

- Julie Bishop, Minister for Foreign Affairs
Some of the soldiers who fought at Villers-Bretonneux

"Australian soldiers won a strategically significant battle here at Villers-Bretonneux on April 24-25, 1918. They helped stop the German offensive and hastened victory for the Allies to restore peace in Europe and the wider world. 

"It is hard to rationalise how this setting, today so sombre and yet serene, could once have been the scene of a ferocious battle, recognised as one of the great Australian victories in World War I.

"No longer the fresh, perhaps naive boys of the Anzac landing three years before, the Australian Imperial Force of 1918 was battle-hardened, canny, and fiercely brave."

- Julie Bishop, Minister for Foreign Affairs
Fort those who fought for us, we salute you. Villers-bretonneux #ANZACDay2014 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/BmCQhmkIIAA4lua.jpg

"Our two nations remain committed to commemoration, in the fervent hope that the horrors of war will never be repeated."

- Ric Wells, Australia's amabassador to France
Australian National Memorial, Villers-Bretonneux
We now move to France and the dawn service ceremony at Villers-Bretonneux.
The dawn service at Gallipoli draws to a close after the playing of the national anthems and a final reading.
Aussies and Kiwis alike united as they honour past generations at Anzac Cove.
Turkey also pays its respects.
The Last Post
Now ... the Last Post

"Though we talk of futility, nobility, horror, loss and gain, and we may argue about the world view of the time and what it meant, we are here in this special place to remember the something greater. To remember the people rather than their purpose. 

"This remembrance is not about glorifying war. It is, rather, about the acknowledgement of the true service and sacrifice of those who gave their all for their countries. 

"This remembrance is something that we would forget or diminish at our peril, and should we diminish their memory, we would be left all the poorer. 

"Words are often hollow. But some are not. Lest we forget."

- Simon Lewis, secretary of the Australian Department of Veterans' Affairs
#Gallipoli Turkey - wreath-bearers at #Anzac Cove 0610 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/BmCU6waIcAA__kV.jpg
Dawn Service at Anzac Cove, Gallipoli #AnzacDay2014 instagram.com/p/nMnzwzEax_/
#Gallipoli - moon above The Sphinx at #Anzac Cove dawn commemoration as light gathers http://pbs.twimg.com/media/BmCRB6pIUAEPuz9.jpg

"The First World War cast a long, dark shadow and ripped our world apart. Now, remembrance ceremonies like this one bring us together. 

"Each year, New Zealanders, Australians and Turks come from the four corners of the Earth to this place, where our grandfathers, great-grandfathers and great-great-grandfathers fought. 

"And where many, many of them died." 

- New Zealand governor-general, Lieutenant General Sir Jerry Mateparae

"While the ANZACs left these shores as a vanquished fighting force, they were, however, victorious in helping forge the identity of our two new nations. 

"And they introduced these new nations to the world. They fought on Gallipoli for eight long months. 

"And after the campaign was over, 8,709 Australians and 2,721 New Zealanders lay dead in the hills and valleys that ring this place of commemoration."

- Michael Ronaldson, Australian Minister for Veterans' Affairs
The official Dawn Service in Gallipoli is underway #Anzac http://pbs.twimg.com/media/BmCO6cRIIAEY2SC.jpg

We who gather here today mourn those who made the supreme sacrifice in defence of values still held so dear. 

They answered their nation's call. They came from every corner of our two great nations to defend freedom. 
- Michael Ronaldson, Australian Minister for Veterans' Affairs
The Anzac Day dawn service has begun in Gallipoli.

Anzac Day commemorations in Brisbane also included a woolier member of the Army.

Private John 'Stan' McArthur VI is a merino sheep donated by Peter and Linda Hacker of Roselea Merino Stud at Muckadilla, Queensland.

'Stan'was enlisted into the Army on November 4, 2009, following a tradition that dates back to February 18, 1971 with the enlistment of the original Private John McArthur into 9 RAR.

Photo by ABC's Peter Lewis
